title: UK growth ‘pushed into rear-view mirror'
text:
Good evening

New data this morning showed the UK economy bounced back in January, driven by growth in the services sector, after a brief setback the previous month from the Omicron variant of coronavirus.

GDP increased by a better than expected 0.8 per cent after shrinking 0.2 per cent in December, meaning the economy was now above its pre-pandemic level.

However, the new figures have been “pushed into the rear-view mirror by renewed domestic and global shocks,” in the words of the head of economics at the British Chambers of Commerce.

As we reported yesterday, economists believe the surge in commodity prices that followed Russia's invasion of Ukraine will worsen the UK's biggest squeeze on disposable incomes for 30 years and reduce growth as inflation peaks above 9 per cent. Hopes that consumer spending could drive growth are also fading. Some are drawing parallels with the Britain of the 1970s.

The UK has few direct economic links with Russia, which accounts for just 1.3 per cent of goods trade, 0.7 per cent of foreign investment, and, unlike for its EU peers, just 4 per cent of gas supplies. But Britain does buy energy and commodities in international markets, where prices are soaring. “The main impact . . . of Russia's invasion of Ukraine is likely to be energy prices staying higher for longer,” said one economist. Food prices are also set to increase.

The worsening outlook puts chancellor Rishi Sunak in a tight spot as he prepares his spring economic statement set for March 23.

According to the IFS think-tank, he will need to find an extra £10bn to avoid a painful pay squeeze for public sector workers whose government pay settlement from last autumn is now being eroded by inflation.

He faces calls to cancel upcoming tax rises as well as demands from his own party to increase defence spending. The one bright spot for him is better than expected public finances.

The uncertainty around the conflict in Ukraine however means few economists are confident in their predictions, or as Investec economist Sandra Horsfield warned: “The longer the war lasts, and the bigger the sanctions on Russia are, the greater the hit to UK activity will be.”

Latest news

  • Draghi says EU members agreed to strengthen defence co-operation

  • US prepares to end normal trade relations with Russia

  • The UK Covid-19 inquiry to examine the country's pandemic response opens a consultation on its draft terms of reference

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

The European Central Bank speeded up the withdrawal of its stimulus programme as the Ukraine conflict fuelled expectations of higher inflation, but it gave itself more flexibility on when to raise interest rates. Frankfurt bureau chief Martin Arnold analyses the hawkish shift in the ECB balance of power.

US inflation hit a new 40-year annual high of 7.9 per cent in February, although the new data covered the period before Russia's Ukraine invasion and the subsequent surge in energy and commodities prices. Goldman Sachs downgraded its US growth forecast for 2022 to 1.75 per cent.

Sanctions have been extended against Vladimir Putin and his associates, including UK action against Roman Abramovich, owner of Chelsea Football Club, with restrictions on its potential sale, as well as on members of the Russian Duma. Dubai meanwhile is becoming a haven for fleeing oligarchs.

Russia was suspended from the Bank for International Settlements while the IMF said its Moscow office was “not operational”. An adviser to the president of Ukraine said Russia had destroyed $100bn of its economic assets. Here's an explainer on the scope for further US sanctions.

Latest for the UK and Europe

A parliamentary report was highly critical of England's £1.1bn catch-up scheme delivered by tutoring company NTP for schoolchildren whose education was disrupted by lockdowns.

Brussels has told EU members to tap the €200bn of unused loans from its pandemic recovery plan before considering more collective borrowing, as member states seek ways of coping with the shocks from the Ukraine crisis.

Global latest

The global energy crisis evolves. The White House is frantically searching for alternatives to Russian oil while the United Arab Emirates is pushing fellow Opec members to increase production. Ukraine warned of the threat to European gas supplies as the Russian army advances. The Lex column examines the potential of alternative sources.

Shanghai is at risk of lockdown as China struggles to contain its biggest Covid outbreak since the pandemic began. Case numbers have tripled in the past week, hitting more than 1,100 across 17 regions and forcing several cities to construct emergency hospitals. The surge has refocused attention on President Xi Jinping's decision to stick with his zero-Covid strategy of tightly sealed borders and — whenever an infection is detected — citywide lockdowns, mass testing and meticulous contact tracing.

Our Big Read examines the rising costs of China's friendship with Russia as it is exposed to market turmoil (it is the world's biggest oil importer) and a diplomatic backlash from much of the rest of the world that views it as Russia's accomplice.

The approval of Argentina's congress of the country's $45bn debt deal with the IMF removed the threat of imminent default on repayments due this year, but investors remain sceptical that the government can deliver on the conditions attached.

Prime minister Narendra Modi's BJP won four out of five of India's state elections, putting the party in a strong position ahead of national elections in 2024.

Need to know: business

The domino effect of international companies quitting Russia continued, with Wall Street giants Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan the latest to announce their departure.

The impact of sanctions and closed markets is taking a heavy toll on the financial sector. BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, reported $17bn in losses on Russian securities and Pimco stands to lose billions if Russia defaults on its debt. Citigroup's long-planned sale of its Russian retail bank is stuck in legal limbo following the invasion of Ukraine, meaning it might have to wind down the operation.

Russian president Vladimir Putin warned however that companies halting operations in his country could have their assets seized. Cat Rutter Pooley says the realities of companies extricating themselves from Russia are going to be slow and complicated.

VW boss Herbert Diess told the FT that the economic damage for Europe from the war in Ukraine could be worse than the pandemic. Shares fell in fellow German carmaker BMW, despite the largest profit in its history of €12.5bn in 2021, on concerns that the crisis would exacerbate supply chain problems and weaken demand for luxury goods.

One of the contributory factors to renewed supply chain concerns is the supply of sailors: Ukraine and Russia account for 14 per cent of commercial seafarers. Aviation war insurers meanwhile are facing their biggest loss since the September 11 terrorist attacks if western-built planes cannot be retrieved from Russian airports.

There are some exceptions to the corporate doom. Hedge fund group Pierre Andurand has enjoyed spectacular gains after betting on rising oil prices. The crypto sector is also likely to benefit, Gillian Tett reports.

A strong bounceback to its highest level of sales ever means British retail bellwether John Lewis will reintroduce its traditional staff bonus and become one of the first retailers to pay staff “the real living wage”. Profit before exceptional items was £181mn for the year to January 29, up 38 per cent from the previous year and more than double the 2020 level.

Columnist John Gapper ponders whether a “superhero surcharge” is the right way for cinemas to recoup some of their lost revenues from the pandemic.

Science round up

A new study published today — the second anniversary of the WHO first labelling Covid-19 a pandemic — indicates the number of global Covid deaths are three times higher than official data suggest.

Scientists identified some of the genetic factors that make certain people more likely to suffer Covid-19 symptoms in the world's largest study of its kind.

High levels of immunity and the reduced severity of the Omicron variant means Covid-19 is less lethal than influenza for most people in England, according to FT analysis.

Moderna pledged not to enforce patents for its Covid jab in low-and middle-income countries following criticism that it was threatening access in Africa.

The UK is stepping up efforts to reach the 9 per cent of the population still unjabbed, focusing on the young and ethnic minorities.  A myth-busting podcast is taking on vaccine misinformation from the infamous Joe Rogan show.

The latest instalment of our Combating Pandemics series examining responses to Covid-19 looks at Africa's attempts to develop its own vaccines and a warning from health groups against “cycles of panic and neglect” as the current crisis appears to fade.

When do we declare the pandemic is over? That's the question posed by science columnist Anjana Ahuja, who says the global co-operation needed to end the emergency and prevent future ones seems more fragile than ever.

Get the latest worldwide picture with our vaccine tracker

And finally...

“The EU predicts that as many as 4mn Ukrainians may join the world's refugee population over the coming weeks and months. If the Home Office can't be moved to offer sanctuary for merely humanitarian reasons, it might consider doing so out of tactical self-interest.” Author William Atkins reviews two new reports on what it's really like to be a refugee.
